Posted: November 22, 2014
												What a fun game for programmers. It's like trying to master a multi-threaded Turing machine simulation or something. I really enjoy the challenge of creating solutions and then optimizing them.Nothing like watching a well designed reactor shuttle molecules around, turn them, bring them together just in time  and the have them carried off somewhere else. Often you make something that works and you have no idea why it works or how you did it. But then you have to go back in and tweak it. Yup, this is exactly what programming is like.My only complaint are the defense missions which often require too much player input - one can't just leave the production line running - and trial and error poking around.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												SpaceChem is an absolutely brilliant chemistry-themed problem solving game. You do not need to know any chemistry to play the game (I finished the game without even understanding periodic table). But you do need to have 'programmer/engineer mindset' such as strong logic, systemic thinking and also spatial thinking.You play as a nameless engineer whose job is to design reactors to turn some molecules into other molecules. Each reactor has two worker circle called waldo. These waldos will travel in certain direction until it got redirected by arrows/symbols, activating anything it passes by, You will then have to place these arrows and symbols in such a way that your waldo will pass an input symbol, perform modifications (such as bonding, debonding, rotating, etc.) to those molecules and then moving the molecules to the output before going back to repeat those actions for the next input until you fulfill your quota.The game has a steady difficulty curve. Each planet starts off with easy levels that teaches you new concepts (such as multiple reactors, sensor & random inputs, fusion, etc.) and ends with a difficult bossfight that tests what you just learned. The game grades you by showing histogram of your speed, symbol count and reactor count compared to other players, giving the incentive to optimize your solution. There are also some optional levels sprinkled around the main campaign and some custom levels placed on research.net that will give you challenges should you want it. You can also create and share custom levels from the editor included in research.net or create some amazing structures in sandbox mode.So for the price it is a must buy if you like problem solving.

Posted: July 4, 2011
												If you thought Portal 2 had challenging puzzles, or if you get scared at the thought of Tetris, then by all means, stay clear of Spacechem. On the other hand, if you love the afforementioned titles, then by all means, do indulge in a puzzlegame based on pure logic and exact science. Incredibly deep and massively engaging, Spacechem's systems and background mechanics will make your brain work like a well oiled V12 engine. In spacechem you have to program a nuclear reactor and assemble, or crack atoms. And that is just the entry level, when you get to einstein level, you have combine your atoms with more atoms, think about bindings, and load them into freighters. While making one compound is a walk in the proverbial park. You have to make make a pattern that is infintely repeatable...on all levels. Making that walk in the park a bloody streetfight in a volcano...in space.

Posted: May 11, 2011
												A stunning puzzle game with an elegance that I have never seen.  The many approaches to any given puzzle allow great flexibility in your solutions. Due to this excellent design you can hone the efficiency of your production line and see how you compare to others or just solve the puzzles.   The idea is remarkable, the design excellent, the interface minimilist and efficient. Posted: December 27, 2011
												Spacechem is less about chemistry and more a programming-puzzle game - You leave signposts on a grid, directing two grabby-thingies and several molecular bonding things to assemble and reassemble molecules.The difficulty curve is a little steep after the first few chapters: it starts you off with making O2 from oxygen, or H2 and O2 from H2O. Eventually, the puzzles become a lot more complex - the one that sticks out in my mind is a boss battle where you are given an infinite supply of water and told to make rocket fuel and plutonium. A later one that has you manufacturing ruby crystals (or a molecule I'm told is supposed to be one) for a laser.That said, it's really rewarding to manage something so complex. -- tl;dr: Puzzles that are hard but not impossibly so. No chem-classes required, but being able to think like a programmer might help.

Posted: May 12, 2011
												TL;DR: Don't buy it if you often say "too long, didn't read."This is an amazing game, but it is designed for people who like to think, seek intellectual challenge in a game, or both. If you didn't understand what that sentence meant, or if it just doesn't apply to you, then SpaceChem is not for you. Don't buy it exclusively for the TF2 items, or you'll have wasted your money by not being able to get them-- the last puzzle is a bit confusing.Nevertheless, if you think you can handle a series of thinking puzzles, go buy it now. Posted: July 2, 2011
												Let's be honest, we all love Lego. Creating things from nothing, being proud of how it works is amazing. K'Nex too~ SpaceChem is the equivalent of combining the two, with some mediocre Chemistry 101. It's not the simplest of games, the learning curve is very steep from the get-go, but once you have it (and you will understand it, trust me) then the possibilities open up. You essentially take one element or molecule, process it, and dump it - rinse, repeat. However there's many challenges, multiple ways to do each challenge and even an online mode you can submit challenges to others! A great, complex, mechanical-inspired, chemistry-laced treat hidden amongst thousands of other indie games.

Posted: October 9, 2011
												This game is EPIC. The challenge is to program reactors with a series of tracks and commands that will produce a specific molecular result. It's far more complicated then it sounds and you have to think on many levels and try to perform the tasks efficiently and in a multitasking manner with the waldos (grabber/activators) that reside in each reactor. One reactor is hard enough, but try stringing together several and producing 2 or more different results to send to different freighters. This is definetly a programmer's game as the system seems remeniscent of a programmable processor that manipulates data and seperates the results to specific outputs. An instant favorite of mine, I'll never tire of looking for the most efficient and effective way to produce the desired output.

Posted: August 26, 2012
												SpaceChem is an absolutely brilliant and unique puzzle game.  Nothing else short of possibly Deadly Rooms of Death can compare to its depth of play while still retaining its simple foundations.SpaceChem is also dastardly tricky.  Most everyone else I know who's played it had to stop because it just got too difficult.  For some levels, I can understand that feeling.  The difficulty curve has spikes in it.  In the end though, I think it's definitely worth it.  The feeling of accomplishment you get is not just from beating the puzzles, but from your own personal solution to them.  You made this design that completed the task set in front of you.  It's yours, every single part of it.There are very few games that can evoke that sort of deeply personal satisfaction.  Of not a job well done, but a machine well made.

Posted: February 26, 2014
												This game is just awesome! Super original, simple, but extremely hard.It consists of a series of puzzles, where you must build a molecule with a pair of "workers", inside a reactor. You must draw those workers' path, and place several activity points along those paths, like grab/drop what you're carrying, wait with other worker, rotate what you're carrying and create bond.You make them pickup the atoms or molecule parts, and synchronize them so that they never let their atoms/molecules collide. Then, to form the molecules you usually have to make it so that one worker is stopped, and the other drops their cargo in the right place, and passes in a "bond" point.From a programmer's point of view, this will basically consist of a series of semaphores and state-machines built using synchronization points. This will all get nastier, when you must build a series of these reactors to build your final molecule...I started trying this for a quick game, and when i noticed, two hours had passed. Very simple to understand and a lot of fun.Beware, though. Don't try to optimize your reactors. You WILL spend the rest of your life doing so..

Posted: May 18, 2012
												In essence this is a programming game. You need to design factories where you program the 2 robots inside to create specific molecules. Later on in the game you need to break-down and/or combine atoms or molecules to create even bigger molecules. While this might sound very sciency, don't expect to learn physics from this. But do expect to learn some (basic) programming and logic from this game. Obviously this game is single player, however, with the leaderboards you can compare your scores with those from friends which is a really nice addition. In fact, I wish more games did this. Be warned though, this game can be very challenging. While challenging, it does give a sense of accomplishment once you beat a level or get an achievement. Highly recommended to geeks!

Posted: July 3, 2011
												Easily the best puzzle game ever, this charming piece of a thinking man's entertainment has also managed to take a spot among my favourite games of all time.SpaceChem doesn't actually have much to do with chemistry, but it has everything to do with programming. The puzzles effectively boil down to designing programs in a language reminiscent of Befunge, and unlike with many puzzle games, there's no feeling at all that you're trying to reproduce the game designer's contrived train of thought. Solutions always feel like a work of your own, and more often than not different people come up with vastly different solutions to the same problem. This alone makes the game extremely rewarding - but there's also a ton of potential for optimizing your solutions; or simply coming up with ones that seem particularly elegant.Add to that a charming soundtrack, extremely competent writing and well over 40 hours of content even without DLC, and this becomes an undisputable must-buy.

Posted: July 13, 2012
												A fun and entertaining puzzle game that, through the medium of fake chemistry, exercises many of the same mental skills as real-world programming.  Like all good games, starts off simply, but expands the tool-set provided to include flip-flops, conditional branches, multithreading, synchronisation primitives, IO, pipelines, and — thanks to the optional listing of your Steam friends' scores — optimisation!Comes complete with a multi-part story, excellent backing music, and a large library of optional challenges. Heartily recommended for all budding programmers.

Posted: August 4, 2014
												Hello,Firstly, SpaceChem is definetely worth the price.  Although you should watch the trailers, or try the Demo.  If you like the trailer, you will probably like SpaceChem, if you enjoyed the Demo, you will nearly guaranteed like the full version.  As of this review I have not attempted the level editor, or made it past the third planet.  The gameplay itself is very difficult after the first 10 levels or so, thus you will most likely be spending a lot of time on this game.  I would like to mention that you should not think "Oh it has "chem" in it, I don't like science so I don't want to do it."  It does have atoms and molecules as its base, but you are not doing real chemistry, so don't let that scare you off.  I previously had problems running it on Windows 8.1, but it turned out to be the game files problem.  That leads me on to the support part of the review.  I found zachtronic's website, and emailed their support about SpaceChem.  It did not take long for them to respond and fix it, so 5 stars for their support!  The only thing this game lacks is a reset button, or maybe I'm missing something.  Anyway, I highly recommend this game if you like puzzles of this sort.

Posted: November 22, 2014
												What a fun game for programmers. It's like trying to master a multi-threaded Turing machine simulation or something. I really enjoy the challenge of creating solutions and then optimizing them.Nothing like watching a well designed reactor shuttle molecules around, turn them, bring them together just in time  and the have them carried off somewhere else. Often you make something that works and you have no idea why it works or how you did it. But then you have to go back in and tweak it. Yup, this is exactly what programming is like.My only complaint are the defense missions which often require too much player input - one can't just leave the production line running - and trial and error poking around.

												This is a fun, challenging puzzle game with a nice story within it. Posted: July 22, 2014
												This game may seem stupid, useless and confusing.It is not. Once you get the hang on the logic of this game, you wont be able to stop playing.Reaction after reaction, bond after bond, you will need all of your patience and alternative thinking to keep up with this game requests.Oh, and do not worry about finishing the game and having no more puzzles to solve. It won't happen.After all this time i passed on SpaceChem and SpaceChem Mobile (Android version, available on the Play Store) i still have 3 entire planets to complete...Also, Research.net releases featured puzzles that you can download and play, and gives you the ability to create your own productions and researches, export them, and import other players work.Reactors have a lot of options in them... varying from normal bonders, to sensors, and even quantum tunnels.Pipelines will mess with your mind, forcing you to find the correct output for the perfect input.Defence missions will test your reflexes and make you give all you have, because if you fail you literally see the planet exploding.The Story (Yes, there is a story!) is complex, relatively long, and i still haven't finished it, because you will unlock it while you play. But it will make you understand a lot of things, so i reccomend spending like 10 mins reading at least the start of it.Optional assignements for Archievents are available to make you you never run out of things to try, and Efficiency Archievements will make sure you will always try to improve yourself.Scoreboards after each puzzle will make you able to see how well and efficiently you programmed your reactor, or pipeline ^^In the end, a great game for the ones that feel like they want to test themselves, but at the same time do not want that test to be boring and repetitive. Every level is different, every reaction has its limits, and it's up to you survive in the universe of SpaceChem.-Cocaine

Posted: July 3, 2011
												This is the puzzle game for methodical and logical minds.  No stupid tricks or anything that breaks logic.  I'm not a huge fan of puzzle games, however SpaceChem is a lot like Incredible Machine, without the plethora of wacky components and mechanics.  Solutions in SpaceChem are typically discovered (rather than planned for immediately), much like a budding mechanical engineer would test things through trial-and-error. Posted: July 5, 2014
												This game is extremely addicting.  The puzzles are very challenging and for some might be frustrating but if you are of an analytical mindset and enjoy programming or logic puzzles you will be in for a great treat with SpaceChem.  One of my favorite aspects of the game is that every single puzzle can be solved in a miriad number of ways (some more elegant and efficient than others) but each unique solution will take a lot of effort to complete and because of that you have a great sense of accomplishment with every one.  Even when you don't have a complete solution the progress you make toward that goal is very enjoyable even if 1/2 way through you realizes a better way to approach the problem and end up scrapping all your work up to that point only to start over from a new direction. The only negative I can give is that the story pane seems very corny and contrived and really unecessary to the game but you can really just ignore that wall of text as it has no bearing on the puzzles or their solution. Highly recommended for puzzle fans. Avoid if your easily frustrated, the difficulty of the puzzles ramps up pretty quickly.

Posted: October 15, 2013
												Great game, but clearly not for everyone (just take a look at the complaints in the forums). While it is a puzzle game, it is nothing like the popular puzzle games out now (e.g. bejeweled and its many clones). The game looks like it should appeal to Chemists, but the people that seem to enjoy and do well in this game are typically software/electrical engineers, computer scientists, mathematicians, and the like. The underlying link seems to be an understanding of programing logic to some extent. (I'm sure there are people that play and enjoy the game that haven't had a lick of programming experience, but I haven't seen many.) Indeed, the chemistry mechanic of the game is secondary and extremely questionable in terms of the reality of it. While I really enjoy this game, there is a *sharp* learning curve. The tutorials can only teach you so much. This again reminds me of computer programing: you can know the basics, but that does not prepare you for the mental exercise of working out a complex challenge. That being said, there are few games that have given me the feeling of accomplishment and pride when I finally work out a solution.

Posted: February 15, 2016
												One of the coolest puzzle games out there. Once you get multiple reactors you have to start thinking about efficiency, and how to prevent waste and blockages. As you go along you'll have to come up with techniques to get reactions flowing more smoothly. I'm half way through the campaign but I feel like I've barely figured out the strategy behind it.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												First off, this game is quite an impressive concept. I bought it on a whim and I have not been disappointed.What you have here is a casually serious game. How's that work? No time limits except for a rare occasion; You can easily stop, reset everything, and try again without repercussion. Make a mistake? Oops! No need for save scumming. Just hit the stop button and try again.(Dusts off highschool chemistry book)... Okay there we go. You may not need this (knocks on book) or be in an episode of Breaking Bad, but understanding how chemistry works is important. You simply cant put an atom here or there, willy-nilly and expect the same product.Timing, Loops, Logic, and Forethought. Being bred into a musical family, the first three I am very capable of. The forethought? Not so much. You have to look at paths, instructions, and syncronization. If you let some parts go without some sort of "wait for blue/red path to reset", you can bork the whole thing in a bink of an eye.While this game gets progressively more difficult, it doesnt leave you hanging. Sure there's going to be some face-planting on the desk, but when you realize that the instruction symbols have other options it changes the game. When your puzzle fails, it will show you where you failed. You just have to figure out why. You dont always have to use BOTH red and blue.The soundtrack music may turn many of you off, but I found it inspirational and motivating. There are not many songs, but they have that "movie" feel. Hard to tell its all synthesized.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												What to say? As far as puzzling games go, this is very, very, very top of the league. What starts out as nearly trivially simple with the first level or two quickly becomes a mind-bender which keeps on busy for ours. The whole is packaged with minimalistic graphics which suite the games just perfect. Any more eye-candy would have been a distraction. The puzzel interface is also well made, with shortcut keys allowing for quick restructuring. What remains is the 'storyline' which  is surely rather minimalistic but still motivating to 'move on' to the next level and see what happens. If you like training your brain with novel ideas, this game is a must-have. Just don't be too hard on yourself if you get stuck over a puzzle for a long time  - finally cracking it is so rewarding! And if you want to get "full value" for your money, try beating other people by finding a yet-more-efficient solution.   In short: This game was simply my best purchase over the last year. Oh, but I'm sure there are lots and lots of gamers out there, which will just hate the game...

Posted: January 14, 2016
												IngredientsServes: 24     225g (8 oz) butter, softened    200g (7 oz) caster sugar    225g (8 oz) dark brown soft sugar    2 eggs    1 dessertspoon vanilla essence    375g (13 oz) plain flour    1 teaspoon bicarbonate of soda    1 dessertspoon hot water    1/2 teaspoon salt    350g (12 oz) dark chocolate chips    125g (4¼ oz) chopped walnutsMethodPrep:20min  ›  Cook:10min  ›  Ready in:30min     Preheat oven to 180 C / Gas mark 4.    Cream together the butter, caster sugar and brown sugar until smooth. Beat in the eggs one at a time, then stir in the vanilla. Dissolve bicarbonate of soda in hot water. Add to batter along with salt. Stir in flour, chocolate chips and nuts. Drop by large spoonfuls onto ungreased baking trays.    Bake for about 10 minutes in the preheated oven, or until edges are nicely browned.

Posted: March 16, 2016
												This game is ♥♥♥♥ing batshit crazy bonkers difficult amazing! Don't be fooled. There is chemistry involved, but what you're really doing is programming. You're assembling molecules on an assembly line, creating bonds, breaking bonds, fusing atoms, etc. with a series of increasingly complicated commands. The game is complex and difficult in its simplicity. Every solution has an obvious solution and 100000 debugging steps. You're limited by the space your track can move on, the inputs and outputs of your reactors, the materials supplied, etc. There are end-of-level comparisons between you and your Steam friends based on the number of elements used ro the cycles needed to finish the goal, so efficiency is encouraged, but sometimes it's absolutely necessary due to constraints, where the level becomes unbeatable because you're missing one teeny tiny space to put "just that one thing down." It's the kind of game where the tutorial makes you feel stupid. Then brilliant. Then the next level they add one teeny-tiny step to the mix and it increases the difficulty tenfold. Then they start adding new mechanics likes switches and sensors and the same basic steps get even more complex. There are bosses at the end of each "world" that test your abilities as they try to destroy your ships and bases.Pros:+Infinite complexity in its simplicity. Here are your tools. Use them however you want.+Great design+AMAZING music. (However, as I played the game for 80 hours, it soon became extremely repetitive, to the point where I memorized the random noises at the beginning of one song. Still, I enjoyed the music so much I didn't mind.)Neutral:~ There's a story, but I actually never read any of it. No idea if it was any good. It's all in text with some simple line art.Cons:- This game is HARD. As I said, it took me 80 hours. I'm not a programmer, so I'm sure it may be easier for others with that background, but I definitely rage quit on the 7th or 8th world and didn't pick the game up again for about 6 months. I ended up looking up solutions for 4 or 5 puzzles after spending upwards of 6 hours on a few of them. Most of what you'll be doing is debugging, fixing tiny problems, optimizing, add one thing, debug, finally figure it out then OH WAIT, twenty cycles down the line there's some random problem that didn't happen in the first 19. Or, make a whole plan, debug debug debug, test it out against the monster and....you missed the opportunity to hit him. Wait, I have to make this action before on command rather than on a set cycle! ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥DELETEEVERYTHINGSTARTFROMSCRATCH%^&*(*$&@)$*$^)!!!!!But, oh, the rapturous joy when I finally beat that final boss without looking up the solution, the sweet tang of victory upon my lips, the 80 hours of hell I went through...finally...worth it.10/10. My mind is melted. You will either transcend to a higher plane of existence where physical bodies are no more, or you will die playing this. There are no other options.

												Step 1: Spend half an hour drawing a diagram on paper of what each reactor roughly should do.Step 2: Spend another hour trying to make those reactors actually do the thing.Step 3: Test your design as a whole.Step 4: Watch as one reactor isn't efficient enough, causing a transport pipe to clog and screw up everything.Step 5: Realize that your entire design is thwarted by one minor flaw you can't seem to fix.Step 6: Get a headache trying to figure out an alternative solution.Step 7: Suddenly think of a much simpler solution that you should have thought of the first time.Step 8: Watch as it works perfectly.Step 9: Look at the leaderboards and see the enormous amount of people who made a simpler, more efficient design.10/10 would slash my wrists open with Occam's Razor again.

												SpaceChem is a very unique puzzle game that somehow managed to draw me in despite my normal lack of appreciation for puzzle games. If you're a fan of logic or programming at all, or if you just like putting together machines and watching them work, then this is a game for you. It's surprisingly intuitive, and despite how easy it is to get into it really manages to ramp up the difficulty in a way that ends up being satisfying rather than frustrating.

												What everyone else says, get this game if you don't give up when solving theorical problems (e.g. math problems) because in that case this game is AWESOME GOTY ALL YEARS, there's no other way to explain how good it is and how much you should be getting it.If you are the type of person that hates solving problems however then you shouldn't get this game at all, you may play a couple levels but will give up on it and hate this game before it even gets to the good parts.Having played this game, if you have a handheld device that can run this game, and you use it when you are in the bus, train, plane or somewhere else where you don't get to do much except sit on your butt, then try to get the spacechem version for that device (I know there's an ipad and android versions for instance), because that's the perfect time to think instead of doing nothing at all.

Posted: August 17, 2013
												Buy? Likely, it's a periodic elemnts based puzzler. At first glance, it looks like something too daunting and requiring you to go back to grade school scient to understand whats going on, but the use of the periodic table is mostly for the theme amd a bit less scientific mechanics of what atom does what. You need to control the circles called "waldos" to grab and drop elements in a reactor to meet the ouput element requirement. This involves finding a way to path the waldos so they grab atoms, possibly bond them together, and put them in the proper output without having the items collide or break apart due to the instructions you give them. Realistically, it's still a bit complicated and I don't think I have the patience or smarts to finish it, but now that I dabbled with the tutorial and understand the mechanics a bit, I DEFINITELY see a solid puzzler for a gamer who wants to test their brain. I got a little joy and entertainment when I figured out how to use syncing of waldos to make the bonds act as needed. If you're in the mood for a good puzzler, look no further.
